Kate Storey-Fisher

Kate Storey-Fisher

PhD Candidate, Center for Cosmology and Particle Physics, New York University

I am a PhD candidate in the Center for Cosmology and Particle Physics at New York University and a NASA FINESST fellow. I study the large-scale structure of the universe—how we can use observations of galaxies and other astronomical objects to understand fundamental cosmological properties. More broadly, I’m interested in the application of data science and statistics to astrophysical problems.

I am also a writer, a public science educator, a "cool TA" (not a regular TA), an open source advocate, a labor organizer, a half-marathoner, and an extremely dedicated member of my book club.

Research

I am currently working on ~three projects, ranging from galaxies to large-scale structure (6 orders of magnitude!).

Anomaly Detection with Deep Learning
I am using Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) to detect anomalous images in the Hyper-Suprime Cam survey. Weird galaxies, active AGN, new gravitional lenses, alien technosignatures - what will we find?!
Emulation of Galaxy Clustering
I am a part of the Aemulus collaboration, building emulators to predict galaxy clustering statistics for any desired parameter set. My current project: emulate the void probability function!
Better Correlation Function Estimation
I am building a new, improved estimator for the two-point correlation function for large-scale structure. It measures galaxy clustering in a continuous basis - no need for binning!

Teaching

Courses

  • Fall 2021: Quantum Mechanics I, NYU (Recitation Instructor)
  • Fall 2019: Quarks to Cosmos (Lab Instructor)
  • Fall 2018: Physics 1, NYU (Recitation Instructor)
  • Fall 2015: Introduction to Object-Oriented Programming and Computer Science, Brown University (Undergraduate Teaching Assistant)

Pedagogy

  • Spring 2019: Design Team Leader, Institute for Scientist & Engineer Educator’s Professional Development Program (ISEE PDP). Led a team to design and teach a workshop on galaxy spectroscopy at CCA.
  • Spring 2018: Participant, ISEE PDP. Designed and taught a workshop on Bayes Theorem at CCA.

Writing

I write for Astrobites, a site by graduate students that summarizes new astrophysics research papers and dishes out other astro-focused content. Some of my recent posts are below.

I’ve also published in the Cooper Square Review; check out my book review of “Hello World” by Hannah Fry.

Meet the AAS Keynote Speakers: Dr. Andrea Dupree
Drop It Like It’s Biased: A Step-by-Step Guide to Dropping the GRE
Iterative Emulation is the Sincerest Form of Parameter Estimation
Morpheus, God of Dreams and Morphological Galaxy Classification
Queer Figures in Astronomy History
Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Resonant Planetary System

Updates

  • September 2021: My work on anomalous galaxy detection with GANs in HSC was published.
  • August 2021: The project I worked on during my stint at the South African Astronomical Observatory on the CGM in the Simba simulations was published.
  • April 20201: I gave a virtual talk to Amateur Astronomers, Inc. in New Jersey on “How Galaxies Shed Light on Dark Matter”.
  • January 2021: I gave a virtual seminar at the German Center for Cosmological Lensing on my correlation function estimator work.
  • December 2020: I virtually attended NeurIPS 2020, where I co-presented a tutorial on ML for Astrophysics, and presented my work on GANs for anomaly detection at the ML4PS workshop.
  • December 2020: I gave the Center for Computational Astrophysics Thursday lunch talk.
  • November 2020: I gave the Princeton/IAS Cosmology Lunch Talk on “binning is sinning”.
  • November 2020: I submitted my first first-author paper!
  • May 2020: I was awarded the NASA Future Investigators in NASA Earth and Space Science and Technology (FINESST) to fund the rest of my PhD!
  • Feburary 2020: I passed my oral qualifying exam to become a PhD candidate!
  • January 2020: I gave a research talk and led a science communication workshop at AAS235 in Honolulu, Hawai’i.
  • December 2019: I was elected co-chair of our new grad student org at NYU, G-PHORCE (Graduate Physics Organization for Research, Culture, and Education).
  • October 2019: I attended the dotAstronomy conference in Toronto (where I made the @arrrXiv twitter bot).
  • September 2019: I presented at GothamFest, New York’s annual festival of astronomy talks.
  • July 2019: I helped author a paper with Astrobites on the site as a model for education and SciComm.
  • July-August 2019: I was a Kavli Student Fellow at the Kavli Summer Program in Astrophysics at UC Santa Cruz, on Machine Learning in the Era of Large Astronomical Surveys.
  • May 2019: I attended the Emulation of Galaxy Clustering workshop at the CCAPP at Ohio State University.
  • March-April 2019: I led a teaching team at the Professional Development Program’s Inquiry institute in Monterey, CA, and the Design Institute in Boulder, CO.
  • December 2019: I completed the Advanced Science Communication Workshop at NYU’s Carter Journalism Institute.
  • July 2018: I attended the Summer School on Large Scale Structure in Berlin.

Outreach

I am involved in outreach programs and events aimed at engaging the public in science and increasing the participation of underrepresented groups in STEM fields.

1000 Girls, 1000 Futures Mentor
I mentor high school girls interested in STEM through the 1000 Girls, 1000 Futures program at the New York Academy of Sciences.
Public Talks
I have given multiple public talks, including an outreach lecture at the South African Astronomical Observatory and a TEDx talk at Brown University. I have also been a guest on the comedy game show Astronaut Training at Caveat in NYC.
Science Puns
Ok, making science puns isn't necessarily outreach, but if I do it on Twitter I think it counts! Check out a punny space thing here, and my punny Halloween costume here.

Service

  • I am on the Science Organizing Committee of the special session Critical Challenges for Machine Learning in Astronomy at the European Astronomical Socity meeting in June 2022.
  • I have refereed for The Astrophysical Journal.
  • I was the founding co-chair of the graduate student organization at NYU, G-PHORCE (Graduate Physics Organization for Research, Culture, and Education).
  • I co-organized the astro-ph journal club in the Center for Cosmology and Particle Physics (CCPP) at NYU.
  • I was on the board of the Women in Physics (WiPhy) group at NYU.

Contact me!

Feel free to get in touch—you could @ me on Twitter, or open a pull request on one of my repos, but probably just send me an email.
